name: Global life sciences industry calls for action on vaccine access
introduction: Trade bodies representing the global life sciences industry have come together to urge coordinated steps to improve access to coronavirus vaccines.
content:
Trade bodies representing the global life sciences industry have come together to urge coordinated steps to improve access to coronavirus vaccines.

In a statement, the groups said: “Immediate action must focus on stepping up responsible dose sharing and maximizing production without compromising quality or safety.”

The call to action has been issued by leading European trade group The European Federation of Pharmaceutical Industries and Associations (EFPIA) and the USA’s Pharmaceutical Research and Manufacturers of America (PhRMA), as well as several other national and regional bodies.

There has been an increased level of concern over the availability of vaccines in lower-income countries, as rich countries move on to vaccinating ever younger and healthier parts of their populations.

Concerns have been made more acute by the evolution of new variants which analysts worry could potentially undermine the protection afforded by existing vaccines.

Globally, new infections have begun to fall from an early-May peak of around 900,000 per day but remain high, with an estimated 681,000 new cases on May 15.

Since the beginning of the pandemic, there have been around 164 million cases of coronavirus, with an estimated 3.5 million deaths.

Steps to broaden access

The global life sciences industry has called on manufacturers, governments, and non-governmental organizations to work together to broaden access to vaccines, with a number of recommendations to improve the situation.

Innovative vaccine manufacturers and biotech companies are being asked to increase dose sharing through COVAX or other efficient mechanisms, and to “expend every effort” to make additional uncommitted COVID-19 vaccine doses available.

They are also being called upon to undertake all practicable efforts to maximize COVID-19 vaccine output, and to eliminate trade barriers, supporting the Coalition for Epidemic Preparedness Innovations' (CEPI's) efforts to create an independent platform for matchmaking and fill and finish capacity.

In addition, the trade bodies have called on manufacturers to support country readiness by partnering with governments, and drive further innovation by prioritizing the development of new COVID-19 vaccines.
